description:
I have my openstack cluster on Havvana.

Resizing an instance (Deb-7-based) to have more disk space - followed by a reboot (soft) - causes the drives to dissapear. And the instance would be hung permanently at the boot screen for it cannot find any drives.

STEPS:
----------
1. Create an instance (deb-7)
2. Resize the instance - with a flavour to have more disk space.
3. After the instance is resized, the instance is permanently set in "ERROR" state - eventhough you can take a console of it and login as usual.

amande@ZZZZZZZ:~/VMs/IMAGES$ nova list
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+
| ID                                   | Name                  | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks                  |
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+
| cc867684-0fe9-48a7-95e9-60890d6e4fd0 | vapp                  | ERROR  | None       | Running     | 172_22-public=172.22.0.49 |
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+

4. Reset state of the instance.

amande@ZZZZZZZ:~/VMs/IMAGES$ nova reset-state --active cc867684-0fe9-48a7-95e9-60890d6e4fd0
amande@axcient:~/VMs/IMAGES$ nova list
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+
| ID                                   | Name                  | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks                  |
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+
| cc867684-0fe9-48a7-95e9-60890d6e4fd0 | vapp                  | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | 172_22-public=172.22.0.49 |
+--------------------------------------+-----------------------+--------+------------+-------------+---------------------------+

5. After it has its state changed, Soft Reboot the instance.

6. right at this stage, the drives are not to be seen. and the instance will be hung at the boot screen forever- for it cannot find any drives to mount.

comments.content:
Amrita, can you give some more information on what causes the initial resize to error out? Are you resizing to a disk size that exceeds your available space, or is there something else going on?

Also, manually changing the error'd out instance to ACTIVE state using nova reset-state --active is not really something that is expected to produce reliable results, in my experience. It's really just an administrative hack and doesn't clean up the instance state -- it simply resets the vm_state to ACTIVE from whatever it was. Can you try doing a reset-state --stopped and then try starting the instance again instead of issuing a SOFT_REBOOT? 

Thanks!

-jay
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~jaypipes

comments.content:
Jay, the resizing, as I have seen, is something that automatically gets instantiated, when (probably) the VM runs to too close to its disk capacity.

Note tyhat the state of the VM never goes to ERROR, for me use the --reset-state.

The resizing when happens, completely freezes the machine, even to the extent that the console isn't more than a blank black screen.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~amande

Amrita, sorry I'm not quite understanding you. You say in your comment above that the state of the VM never goes to ERROR, but in the bug description, you have:

"3. After the instance is resized, the instance is permanently set in "ERROR" state - eventhough you can take a console of it and login as usual."

Also, AFAIK, there are no automatic resizes of VMs in Nova...

What version of libvirt and libguestfs are you running? Can you attach your entire (sanitized) config so we can see the rest of the libvirt config? Seems like libguestfs is failing, which I expect is related, but I don't know why.

Nova definitely does *not* do automatic resizes, so I'm very curious about that...
